bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to John Pemberton, February 14 and March 28, 1721

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to Liverpool merchant, John Pemberton, February 14, 1721, that he has received the shoes, but they are not as strong as he desires. He orders more, and is quite specific that they are not to be black because those rot quickly in Virginia. He alerts Pemberton to a bill of exchange drawn on him to Samuel Bousch, and notes that he would have sent tobacco on board Captain Hancock's ship but the freight rate was too high. He encloses a bill of lading for 30 hogsheads of tobacco sent on this ship. In a brief postscript, he reports a bill of exchange. In a longer postscript dated March 28, 1721, Carter orders 3-400 bushels of salt and 4-500 yards of strong Liverpool linen. He expects to ship 30 or 40 hogsheads of tobacco on the Content if Capt. Stephenson will accept £9 per ton freight charge. In his own hand, Carter adds another postscript requesting Pemberton find two indentured servants to replace John Babe, a clerk, and Marget Upton, the best female servant Carter has ever had.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to John Pemberton, February 14 and March 28, 1721

opener.dateline:
Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
Febr. 14. 1720/21
Mr. John Pemberton

div1.p:
Yor. Goods in Hancock came Safe Yor. Shoos are
not half so strong as I would have them & made of black leather
wch. always proves rotten Such as Yor. Carrmen and Plowmen
wear are the fittest for us I would desire You to take the first
opportunity You meet with to Send me 6 Doz more of the
best plain Shoos You can buy, 2 Doz. of the 16s. 2 Doz of the 14s. & 2 Doz
of the 12s. and lett them not be made of black Leather
Yor. per[s]onal care in this matter will very much oblige me

The 24th of Decr. I drew a bill on You for £55"17"9
payable to Collo. Samuel Boush wch. I must desire You to answr.
when It comes to hand but that I reckon will not be till
towards the latter End of the Summer,

I would have put Some Tobo. on board Hancock
but nothing less than £10 per Tun would be Accepted by him
wch. I could by no means give, I have mett with a stranger
[who] hath bin a little more Moderate, herewith I send You a
bill of Lading for 30 hogsheads of Stript Leaf Tobo. my own Crop
which God sending It safe I hope You'l have no reason to
Complain of I conclude at present
div1.seg:
I have drawn on [you] toCapt. Nat. Milby for
£3"1S the Impst. of the Tobo.
A Postscript to Mr Pemberton's Lettr.
Dated Feb. 14th. 1720/21
Mar. 28. 1721
Sir——
The above is a copy, of mine per Milby the cheif [sic] end of this
is to Desire You to take the first opportunity You meet with not only to
Send me in the above shoos, but also three or four hundred bushells
of Yor. Salt and likewise four or five hundred Yards of Yor. Strong
Leverpool linnen, I am in Treaty with Captn. Stephenson the
present Mr of the Content for some Freit if he will take £9
per Tun I design You 30 or 40 hogsheads more of my Stemmed Tobo. I request
Yor. Care of the Lettrs. that accompany this and am Sir
Yor. humble Servt.
Twenty Odd Years agoe You sent me by Captn.
Woodward two very good Servts John Babe
an extraordinary good writer & Marget
Upton the best woman Servt I ever had in
my Family Since I was Master of one
she married very well after she was free
if You could recommend two Such Servts
now It would be a very acceptable Favor.

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1720 July-1721 July, BR 227, Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens, San Marino, California. Printed: Wright. Letters of Robert Carter. . . . pp. 76-77. The postscript of March 28th appears on page 92.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.
The post script to the March 28, 1721, addition to the letter of February 14, 1721, is entirely in Carter's hand as is indicated by the use of italics.

[1] Samuel Boush (d. 1739) was a justice and sheriff of Norfolk County for many years, and a large landowner (Torrance. Virginia Wills and Administrations,1632- 1800. p. 44; and McIlwaine. Executive Journals of the Council. . . ., 3(1705- 1721): 171, 180, 543, etc.

[2] The impost was the duty imposed by Britain on imported tobacco, and the cocket, for which a fee was charged, was the document bearing a cocket or seal issued by the "King's Customs House" that the impost had been paid. (See the definitions of each word in Oxford English Dictionary Online.)
